The Substance of the
Frenche Kinges
answeare to M
r
Bodleyes message May 1588.
fol.226r
The effect of
e K. answear was, that he found
more kindnes in his good sister
e
Q. of England
then in all
e Princes his frindes and allies besides,
in that is pleased her to send so carefully and circum-
spectly to him, in his troblesome state: w
ch
was no
newes unto him, for that her proceedinges heretofore
had alwaies bin suche. And for his owne part he
would endevo
r
to deserve it, w
t
all maner of princely
and brotherly correspondence, whensoever and as often
as
e occasion is presented. He could never th
a
ke
her sufficiently, in that it pleased her to take part
of his grief, uppon that accident of
Paris
, w
ch
was
so great sometimes as it made
e teares in his eies.
Howbeit he was not
e first Kinge that had bin so in-
treated in
Fraunce
or els where: and for his owne part
made no dout, but God would so assist him in his
just cause, as
e shame of all in
e end should falle
uppon themselves. And as for those particular
offers of succo
r
and helpe, w
ch
his good sister made
unto him, he were to be accounted
e most ungrate-
full man that liveth, if he should not esteeme
them as singular courtesies. Nevertheles a great nomber
of his owne good subjectes as well nobles as others
had bin w
t
him, and offered their service w
t
suche
ready good will and devoti
o
, as he made no dout
but w
t
his owne forces and power to be able suffi-
ciently to chastise his ennemies: and in
e end the
world should perceave, that he would not putt up un-
revenged so manifest indignities.
